name: Altair
description: Altair races through space with astonishing speed, spinning so fast it bulges at its equator. In the myth of the Weaver and the Cowherd, Altair stands as the separated lover across the river of stars, waiting for the single night each year when the bridge of magpies forms.

name: Deneb
description: Deneb is a luminous supergiant — one of the most distant stars visible to the naked eye. In the ancient skies of the Middle East, it was the tail of the celestial swan flying along the Milky Way, guiding souls across the river of night.

name: Spica
description: Spica is a blazing blue-white binary, its components locked in a close gravitational embrace. In antiquity, it symbolized the ear of wheat in the hand of Virgo, marking the rhythm of harvests and the returning cycle of life.

name: Antares
description: Antares glows like a smoldering coal in the heart of Scorpio. Its ancient name means 'rival of Mars,' for the two once fought for dominance in the night. It is a dying supergiant — vast, unstable, and magnificent.

name: Fomalhaut
description: Known as the 'Lonely Star' of the southern sky, Fomalhaut shines alone in a wide expanse of darkness. Surrounded by a great ring of dust, it is the eye of the celestial fish in ancient Arabian star-lore.

name: Aldebaran
description: Aldebaran burns with a steady copper flame, the eye of Taurus the Bull. Many cultures saw it as a watchful guardian of the winter sky, overseeing the passage of seasons and the migrations of people and stars alike.

name: Regulus
description: Regulus is the heart of the Lion — Leo — bright and regal. It spins so rapidly that it bulges at the equator, a crown of fire stretched thin by its own motion. In Persian astronomy, it was one of the Four Royal Stars of Heaven.

name: Pollux
description: Pollux burns with warm golden light and hosts a giant planet. In myth, Pollux was the immortal brother — a light that remains after all else fades.

name: Castor
description: Castor is not one star, but six — a gravitational family bound in luminous choreography. It is the mortal brother in myth, brilliant yet destined to fade.

name: Procyon
description: Procyon rises before Sirius, heralding the coming of the great winter star. It has a faint white dwarf companion — the burned-out core of a sun that once shone bright.

name: Capella
description: Capella is a pair of giant suns locked in a slow and dignified orbit. In ancient Greece it represented Amalthea, the celestial goat who nourished Zeus — a light of protection and nurturing grace.

name: Bellatrix
description: Bellatrix is the Amazon Star — the Warrior of Orion. Though smaller than Rigel or Betelgeuse, it shines with fierce clarity, a beacon of courage in the celestial hunt.

name: Saiph
description: Saiph marks Orion’s knee — a blue-white blaze of intense heat. Its brilliance masks a truth: much of its light lies in wavelengths the human eye cannot see, burning beyond sight.

name: Dubhe
description: Dubhe is one of the two pointer stars guiding navigators to Polaris. It has served travelers for centuries, a steady flame in the turning wheel of the night.

name: Merak
description: Merak stands with Dubhe as a guidepost in the sky, pointing the way to true north. Together they mark the bowl of the Big Dipper — a celestial map etched in light.

name: Mizar
description: Mizar and Alcor are the ancient eye test of the desert caravans — two lights so close that the sharp-eyed could distinguish them. Today we know Mizar is itself multiple stars entwined.

name: Alcor
description: Alcor travels beside Mizar across the heavens. In many cultures, the ability to see the pair marked keen vision — not just of eyes, but of spirit.

name: Elnath
description: Elnath is the horn of Taurus, pointed toward the heart of the sky. It gleams with an icy blue fire, a spear of starlight thrust toward eternity.
